WRITING.TEXT: That's basically how I understand it for the class being engaging part. The students liking each other part seems a little different. Students were more likely to sync up if they reported liking each other, but only if they'd talked with each other before class. This suggests that face-to-face social connection plays a role too.

Oh wow. That GIF is fantastic.
Especially amazing that they not just survived, but seem to have developed into normal, fully functioning animals. I'm really curious to see if they're successful at getting the approval to try this on humans in the 3-5 years they're estimating.
Here's the study: https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms15112

WRITING.TITLE: 3D printers can now print glass. As reported in Nature, a newly designed "Liquid Glass" can take the place of a typical 3D printer resin. When the resulting product is heated, it becomes pure fused silica glass.
To Change Politics, Do More Than March for Science

WRITING.TEXT:
What do you make of [recent research](https://www.researchgate.net/blog/post/antibiotics-given-early-in-life-may-have-lasting-negative-effects) suggesting that antibiotics early in childhood might have lasting negative effects on things like brain development, gut microbes, and social behavior? This seems very preliminary (I think just documented in mice so far), but still very troubling.
I know you specialize more in viruses and vaccines, but this seems very reminiscent of concerns about vaccines.
My parents tried to go in with a neighbor to do this with a tiny plot of trees between their houses. They were not rich enough.

21st century medicine might be era of the gut biome. Because it seems to have a hand in a lot of stuff.
Agreed 100%. I think figuring out which bacterial compositions do what may be as big for medicine as figuring out "germs" exist in the first place.

I like that this includes the aspect of probiotics to mitigate the effect (and wish there was more of a focus on it). Long-term effects aside, you can't just not give sick kids antibiotics if they need them.
Here's the peer-reviewed study: http://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms15062

a reminder that fieldwork remains a valuable tool for discovery in an era of indoor genetic labs.
This is my favorite part of this study.
Anybody know what that drug is for and what it's approved to do in humans?

WRITING.TEXT:
While I gather that teaching to tests is awful for kids, I wonder if teachers get away with this less now with all the standardized testing.
Had the same thing in Ancient and Medieval History in 9th grade. The teacher had Greek heritage. It started out normal: a unit on Mesopotamia, one on Egypt, one on the Hebrews. Then came an Athens unit. Then a Sparta unit. Then a separate unit on the Peloponnesian War. Then a handful of other Greece units. Never got to Rome. Definitely never got to the medieval part.
On the other hand, he was a great teacher in other respects. Learned a ton about the process of doing history, which is in retrospect probably more important anyway than what we actually studied.

US education varies a lot from state to state, and from teacher to teacher. In my experience, WWI and WWII were on the curriculum. But because we went through things roughly chronologically, we never actually got to them due to bad time management by teachers.
Had a whole year of "Modern European History," but we never made it much past the industrial revolution. Had a day each for WWI and WWII at the end of the year.

I'd imagine that blood spurts out pretty fast and looks straight in person (probably why Caravaggio painted it that way). I guess the point is that knowing the physics behind projectile motion changes the way you imagine it coming out frozen mid-spurt. Not been to many beheadings myself, so I can only speculate.
